Since then, I‚Äôve taken part in multiple quests and it‚Äôs helped me grow in more ways than one; sharpening my skills and shifting my mindset. name: David Pratama
tweet: When I first joined Quira in February 2025, my friends recommended trying a quest ‚Äî like a hackathon ‚Äî called Quira. üßµ

thread.tweet: At first, I thought Quira was just like Devpost ‚Äî a platform for hackathon-style projects. The UI/UX impressed me right away: smooth, simple, and easy to use.
For my first quest (Quest 25), I almost didn‚Äôt join. Many participants were highly skilled professionals, and I felt anxious and unsure about what I could build.
After 2‚Äì3 days of debating, I joined anyway ‚Äî with a new mindset: "Success can only be reached if you start from zero." That gave me the motivation to create something useful for others.
When I submitted my project, I had no expectation of winning. The other entries were amazing ‚Äî far beyond what I had imagined.
Then came the announcement at the Opera House for Quest 25. To my shock, my project was in the Top 2, featured in Rodrigo‚Äôs presentation. I was thrilled and couldn‚Äôt believe it.
That moment made me decide to join every future Quest or Solve Challenge as soon as I can. Huge thanks to friends like Rodrigo, you, Om, and others who‚Äôve supported me!

name: Spandan Mukherjee
tweet:
When I first joined @quira_sh , I thought it‚Äôd just be ‚Äúanother community server.‚Äù
I was wrong. It became one of the best decisions I‚Äôve ever made online. üßµ

thread.tweet:
On my first day, I was just a quiet member, exploring channels and trying to figure out how everything worked.
The welcoming vibe made me stay. The curiosity made me explore more.

Then came my first Quest.
Helping someone solve a problem, sharing resources, or even just being part of a discussion ‚Äî I realized Quira isn‚Äôt about clout, it‚Äôs about building each other up.

Somewhere along the way, I became a Dev Advocate.
Not just a title ‚Äî it meant I could guide others, share my experiences, and help newcomers feel the same way I felt on Day 1: welcome.

I‚Äôve grown here ‚Äî not just as a dev, but as a person.
From learning in public, to leading initiatives, to meeting people who inspire me daily‚Ä¶ @quira_sh has been the bridge between potential and progress.

If there‚Äôs one thing I‚Äôve learned:
Communities aren‚Äôt made of rules or channels ‚Äî they‚Äôre made of people who care. @quira_sh is living proof of that. üíú

Thank you, @quira_sh.
Thank you for the friendships, the growth, the laughs, and the challenges.
If you‚Äôre reading this and wondering if you should join ‚Äî trust me, it‚Äôs worth it. ‚ú®

name: K Om Senapati
tweet:
Back when I barely knew CS, I found @quira_sh

They ran Creator Quests ‚Üí mini hackathons with swag and cash. I joined one, learnt more in a week than months before, built something small but cool. I even won a couple of quests.

thread.tweet:

name: Chirag Aggarwal

It made me learn a ton about os, helped me land my first internship in os, and gave me everlasting memories.
Thank you quira, for everything ‚ù§Ô∏è

name: Abinand P
tweet: My open source journey began almost by accident during Hactoberfest 2024, when a Quira bot comment on GitHub caught my attention. What started as curiosity turned into a deep dive into professional codebases through @quira_sh "solver quests."üßµ

thread.tweet: The community became my hands-on classroom, teaching me how real-world development works: fast-paced, collaborative, and far beyond what textbooks could offer.

Through Quira, I contributed to projects like Permit.io and Daytona, each pushing me outside my comfort zone and sharpening my skills in developer tooling. the biggest lesson I've learned is that growth comes from collaboration and learning in public.
I began knowing nothing about open source, here Quira started it and now I'm an active contributor, ready to take on improving next developer tooling.

tweet: I joined the @quira_sh community a while ago, but really got involved about a year back. Since then, I‚Äôve met amazing developers, dove into quests, and contributed to open-source projects like @MindsDB, @CopilotKit, @daytonaio & @CyclopsUI. Learned a lot and earned along the way.

tweet: a year back, i was just tryna find ways to make some cash for my spendings.. randomly came across quira through some open source event.. joined my first quest, didn‚Äôt feel great, codemonkey (the first great thing i built) lost it, but learnt a ton that month while i was broke af

thread.tweet: i was just tryna find ways to make some cash for my spendings.. randomly came across quira through some open source event.. joined my first quest, didn‚Äôt feel great, codemonkey (the first great thing i built) lost it, but learnt a ton that month while i was broke af

tried again the next month, same result loll, but yeah this time it was kinda on me.. @rrs00179 (the dumb one) convinced me to give it another shot, and that‚Äôs when things flipped.. got my first win, and after that, never really stopped.. met a few cool folks along the way.
so yeah, thanks @quira_sh. for showing up, for teaching me stuff, and for letting me grow.

name: Lymah
tweet: Quira.sh has been a great platform for open source contributors who want to learn and earn with their contributions through bountiful quests. I even got my second sponsor on GitHub thanks to Quira.sh. Not only that, but you also have the opportunity to be part of a supportive community through their Discord channel. I did have an issue with withdrawing my first loot, but the DevRel, a person named Rohan, came through for me and made it possible for me to receive it via GitHub Sponsors.
